title.narrative: The Women Delegates Fund

description.narrative: The goal of the WDF is to enhance women's full and equal participation in all aspects of climate change decision-making and ultimately, to promote the achievement of gender equality and improve the success of climate change actions at all levels by ensuring they are gender-responsive. The program has three key objectives. Objective 1: Enable women delegates to participate effectively in climate change dialogues/negotiations and decision-making. Strategy: Travel support for up to 5 women delegates to all intersessionals and COPs between 2016-2020, in addition to on-site logistical and technical support during the meetings. Objective 2: Enhance the content knowledge and negotiation capacity of women delegates. Strategy: Training on negotiations skills/ UNFCCC processes for new women delegates; technical dialogues for participants on a range of topics during meetings; participation in key regional processes for key delegates Objective 3: Raise awareness of the importance of gender-responsive climate policy and women’s leadership in climate change decision-making through outreach and advocacy. Strategy: Research and data tracking on women’s effective participation and leadership; publishing and disseminating results via publications and side events.

WEDO, an international women’s advocacy organization, has been involved in the UNFCCC process for close to a decade and is committed to ensuring women’s active and equal participation in these critical negotiations, as well as that women’s rights and gender equality are integrated into the outcome agreements, programs and related funds. As part of its portfolio of programming on gender and climate change, WEDO has implemented a special project since 2009, the WDF, with additional support from the Government of Finland, the Government of the Netherlands and in partnership with UNDP and the Global Gender and Climate Alliance (GGCA). The WDF sponsors women from developing countries, particularly Least Developed Countries, to participate on their national negotiating delegations to major UNFCCC meetings and provides a comprehensive capacity building program, implementing trainings and workshops, networking and communication activities for the participants, in addition to travel support.

title.narrative: # of supported women delegates taking on leadership roles within their delegations
# of supported women delegates taking on leadership roles within their delegations

comment.narrative: Each of the five WDF delegates took on leadership roles within their delegations and/or regional groups. Ms. Winfred Lichuma was appointed Co-Chair by the SBI of the informals on gender and climate change. Ms. Stella Gama was lead on technology issues for LDCs and lead for LDCs on gender and climate change. Ms. Chu Thi Thanh Huong was leading her delegation on mitigation and NDCs discussions. Ms. Madhu Ghimire and Ms. Aria Neaeesh were both leading on gender and climate change for their countries.
Five of the twenty WDF delegates at the SB50 negotiations indicated taking on some level of leadership in their delegations.

Ms. Stella Gama appointed as SBSTA rapporteur for the next meeting in 2019. She remains a member of the Technology Executive Committee. National Gender and Climate Change Focal Points: Ms. Tayech Ourgicho Didemo (Ethiopia), Ms. Josephine Doles (Liberia), Mrs. Antonine Clara Raharisoa (Madagascar), and Ms. Maryam Basheir Elfeel (Sudan) serve in these roles. At least three additional delegates strive to be appointed to this role. Ms. Charlotte Pihigia co-led her Niue delegation of 2. Other delegates reported back on the themes they followed and aided in coordinating their delegations but due to the difficulties of quantifying these qualitative contributions, are not included in the number above.
There was no Conference of the Parties this year in which women delegates could take on leadership roles on their delegations.
There was no intersessional negotiation session this year in which women delegates could take on leadership roles on their delegations.
This indicator cannot be reported due to the virtual nature of the SBs this year.
This indicator would be reported bi-annually (in a year not disrupted by pandemic).

% women heads of national environmental-sector ministries

location.ref: Gender and Environment: Support Kit for UN Staff

comment.narrative: Base data set has not been updated. WEDO will undertake its own data set for this indicator in 2018.
New effort to systemically collect this data undertaken April-May 2019; looking into incorporation onto the WEDO website.

This data, from IUCN's Environment & Gender Index, is comparable with the 2015 data (reported 2016); the 2018 and 2019 reporting each used a different methodology. Source: https://www.iucn.org/news/gender/202103/new-data-reveals-slow-progress-achieving-gender-equality-environmental-decision-making
This dataset was not able to be updated for 2021.

title.narrative: # of countries that develop national gender and climate action plans to implement NDCs
Countries that have gender and climate change action plans

description.narrative: 16 national governments (IUCN, 2015) (Nepal, Liberia, Tanzania, Mozambique, Jordan, Egypt, Arab League of States regional process, Central America regional process, Panama, Costa Rica, Haiti, Bangladesh, Cuba, Yucatan Peninsula, Peru)

comment.narrative: be developing these plans outside the IUCN format (IUCN, 2015): Sudan, for example, has a plan of this type. WEDO plans to outreach to the new network of National and Gender Climate Change Focal Points in 2019 to get a better sense of where these plans exist

title.narrative: Countries that have included gender or women in NDCs

description.narrative: In total, 64 of the 188 INDCs analyzed include a reference to women or gender. Of these, several only mention gender in the context of the country’s broader sustainable development strategy and not specifically in relation to climate change policies (e.g. India). (WEDO, publishing date 08/2016)

comment.narrative: By the end of 2021, 110 new and updated NDCs were analyzed; 93 included a reference to gender or women.

In total, 65 NDCs analyzed include a reference to women or gender. Of these, several only mention gender in the context of the country’s broader sustainable development strategy and not specifically in relation to climate change policies (e.g. India). (Internal WEDO Reporting. See the Gender Climate Tracker App) Of six "first" NDCs published since then, three contained a reference to gender. Of 14 "updated" NDCs analyzed (those published by 8 Dec 2020; later Dec releases still undergoing analysis), 7 contained a reference to gender. Of 4 second/new NDCs analyzed (those published by 8 Dec 2020; later Dec releases still undergoing analysis), all 4 contain a reference to gender.

In total, 65 NDCs analyzed include a reference to women or gender. Of these, several only mention gender in the context of the country’s broader sustainable development strategy and not specifically in relation to climate change policies (e.g. India). (Internal WEDO Reporting. See the Gender Climate Tracker App) Of six first NDCs published since then, three contained a reference to gender. The second NDC published by the Marshall Islands also contains a reference to gender; the first one did not.

title.narrative: # of mandates on gender included in decisions of the UNFCCC and subsequent bodies on the implementation of the Paris Agreement
# of mandates on gender included in decisions of the UNFCCC and subsequent bodies on the implementation of the Paris Agreement

description.narrative: WEDO does not include references that refer to human rights, stakeholders or socially sound measure in our methodology for counting gender mandates.

comment.narrative: No increase since 2019; no negotiated decisions in this pandemic year.
